stream_context.summary: Kaze spends most of the stream sick, fighting a nearly-full SSD, and then resumes grey-boxing the new island overworld. He re-evaluates layout, merges sections, and places course entrances while brainstorming secrets, gating mechanics, and set-pieces.

development_findings.summary: The original overworld was scrapped and replaced by a single, much larger overworld level now being grey-boxed in parts.
development_findings.quote: The original overworld is completely erased. It's just not up to the quality standards.

development_findings.summary: Parts 5 and 7 were merged after Kaze realised the lower beach area was meant to be a separate zone, necessitating a redesign of entrances and flow.
development_findings.quote: What happened is this whole bottom area here was supposed to be a different area. That's why this sucks so much. Now it all makes sense.

development_findings.summary: The hub’s design goal is an island that "feels like there are secrets around every corner," including caves, hidden forest loops, sandcastle blue-coin mini-games and optional retro sub-areas that reference but do not copy Yoshi’s Island.
Course 6 will be a "Jurassic Jungle" with prehistoric Yoshis that have talons; a bug currently prevents showing the level in-engine.
development_findings.quote: Course 6's theme is Jurassic Jungle, it's a prehistoric jungle level with ancient Yoshis.

development_findings.summary: Access to the volcano (Part 12) will be gated by a climbable ‘super-happy-tree seedling’ that appears once the player has collected enough ‘happiness’.
development_findings.quote: Or if you collect enough happiness on the island, you can climb up here.

development_findings.summary: A grate or secret shortcut is being considered to control how the player interacts with the central river path.
development_findings.quote: Do we make it so that if you fall down the river, you come back out in part one… I guess we can also just make a grate.

development_findings.summary: Multiplayer is on the wish-list; technically feasible but boss fights like Raven would be "really weird" and janky.
development_findings.quote: I don't know if multiplayer is going to be in the game… it's mostly boss fights that are going to be jank with it.

development_findings.summary: The project now uses the Mario 64 decomp engine with Kaze’s custom step function, eliminating thin invisible-wall issues found in vanilla.
development_findings.quote: My game uses a whole different step function… hitting an invisible wall just doesn't happen anymore.

development_findings.summary: Current ROM size is just under 60 MB; overall progress estimate is roughly 10 percent complete.
development_findings.quote: I think we're maybe like 10% done.

development_findings.summary: Future plan: run individual course play-tests (starting with Course 11) to gather more granular feedback.
development_findings.quote: Today, I'm going to try to find someone to play-test it again… get more play-test data.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is feverish and exhausted, which cuts the stream short.
context_findings.quote: Today I'm feeling miserable… I'm feeling very exhausted today.

context_findings.summary: A full system drive prevented him from opening Photoshop; earlier SSD failure already cost him undocumented hack code.
context_findings.quote: My old SSD broke and I lost a little bit of work… a lot of documentation, which kind of sucks.

context_findings.summary: Financial pressure: he has lined up multiple sponsor spots (NordVPN, Squarespace, Brilliant) to support his family.
context_findings.quote: I gotta make money for my family. I'm gonna have to make so many videos for all these sponsors.

context_findings.summary: He wants smaller, riskier, more creative games instead of expensive, ‘safe’ AAA products.
context_findings.quote: Let's start making games again… not the 'throw six million dollars at it and make something very safe' type games.

context_findings.summary: He finds computers frustrating; prefers building new systems over learning other people’s systems.
context_findings.quote: With computers you're just learning about things someone else made. It's not like you're making new systems.

context_findings.summary: Personal hopes: his child will like Mario 64, otherwise he jokes he'll be the "lamest dad at school."
context_findings.quote: She'd think I'm so lame if she doesn't like Mario 64.

biobak.summary: Spotted a symmetry issue in Course 2’s disco area; provides ongoing environment feedback.
biobak.quote: Biobak: what's wrong… Is it something in course 2 that I fucked up the symmetry?

zeina.summary: Created concept art for a time-shifting cave; Kaze is trying to adapt it to a 3D space.
zeina.quote: This is what Zeina had… I do want it to be a cave.

key_stories.title: SSD Meltdown
key_stories.summary: While sick, Kaze discovers his C-drive is almost full; Photoshop cannot open work files. He spends half the stream deleting programs and cache files, eventually freeing 5 GB.
key_stories.challenge: Critical art file would not open because the SSD had only 1.6 GB free.
key_stories.process: Uninstalled unused programs, deleted cache folders, ran Windows disk cleanup while chatting with viewers.
key_stories.outcome: Photoshop finally opens; reveals earlier SSD crash that permanently erased undocumented hack code.
key_stories.key_quote: This was very annoying… my old SSD broke and I lost a little bit of work to that.

key_stories.title: F3 Rejection Anecdote
key_stories.summary: Kaze recounts rejecting a would-be modder (‘Roman’) from the F3 showcase for only having one week of progress on a Galaxy-style hack; the mod never advanced.
key_stories.challenge: Applicant tried to enter F3 with minimal progress, expecting acceptance.
key_stories.process: Kaze denied the submission, explaining likelihood of non-completion; the applicant vowed to prove him wrong.
key_stories.outcome: Seven years later no further progress was made; illustrates Kaze’s gatekeeping philosophy to maintain quality.
key_stories.key_quote: He had a title screen and a T-posing Mario… I rejected him because this is probably never gonna get finished.
